children.value: When tabbing through the carousel, the focus moves from slide 1 to slide 2, then to the arrows, and finally to the dots. It never reaches slide 3 unless the user interacts with one of the navigation UI elements.
feature isn"t friendly to keyboard navigation and is disabled once the user starts interacting with the carousel using the tab key. Clicking on the carousel restores looping.

props.code:
<ssr-carousel :slides-per-page="2" show-arrows show-dots loop peek="80">
  <slide :index="1" to="#1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2" to="#2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3" to="#3"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>

children.value:
<ssr-carousel :slides-per-page="2" show-arrows show-dots loop peek="80">
  <slide :index="1" to="#1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2" to="#2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3" to="#3"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>
You can set the initial index with

to track the current index from your component.
With

, adjusting the value will change the current page. However, if you use a non-0 starting
index,

will jump to your selected page when it has a chance to measure the size of your slides. If
you want to prevent this flicker, you may want to prevent showing
Interact with demo to view events
Numbers values are treated as pixels
You can even use CSS custom properties

links.text: Numbers values are treated as pixels
You can even use CSS custom properties

contents.title: Introduction
contents.description: A performance focused Vue carousel designed for SSR/SSG environments.

children.value: A performance focused Vue carousel designed for SSR/SSG environments.
Looping with multiple slides per page
Note how the incomplete 2nd page is handled. The 3rd and 1st slide are shown simulataneously. On the next advance forward, the track advances a half width so that the
first page contains the 1st and 2nd slide.
, a useful pattern for focusing on a featured slide, like in a product carousel.
components to render image assets. Note how lazy loading prevents the loading of the second image until you advance forward.

props.code:
<ssr-carousel loop>
  <slide>
    <NuxtImg
      src="https://via.placeholder.com/1920x1080?text=Slide+1"
      loading="lazy"
      width="1920"
            height="1080">
    </NuxtImg>
  </slide>
  <slide>
    <NuxtImg
      src="https://via.placeholder.com/1920x1080?text=Slide+2"
      loading="lazy"
      width="1920"
            height="1080">
    </NuxtImg>
  </slide>
</ssr-carousel>

links.text: Looping with multiple slides per page

children.value: Carousel is disabled when fewer slides than viewport
Note how this carousel is enabled on mobile viewports but automatically disables on wider viewports.

props.code:
<ssr-carousel
  show-arrows
  show-dots
  loop
  :peek="20"
  :slides-per-page="3"
  :responsive="[
    {
      maxWidth: 767,
      gutter: 10,
      slidesPerPage: 1
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>

children.value:
<ssr-carousel
  show-arrows

  loop
  :peek="20"
  :slides-per-page="3"

      maxWidth: 767,

>

Slide images and anchors can be dragged
This is a challenge for some carousels, dragging on an image or anchor results in dragging a ghost image of the element rather than the slide.

Autoplay is typically used in conjunction with
, stay externally reactive as you'd expect. This includes slides cloned for peeking.
Carousel doesn't render until there are slides
on the root element will cause
render a new instance. In other words, your pagination page will be lost and any animations in slides will restart. Generally, you should strive to have all slides ready for render on the initial
to benefit from the SSR features of the component.

children.value: This is an example of implementing peeking on the right side only, which is useful for teasing the presence of other cards.
when using a left peek so that space is filled on the first page.
Note how there is only one more slide than the amount we're showing per page. The last slide gets cloned so it peeks in on both the left and right sides. This example also uses the

props.code:
<ssr-carousel loop :slides-per-page="3" :peek="40" show-arrows>
  <slide
    v-for="(color, index) in ['red', 'orange', 'yellow', 'green']"
    :key="color"
    :index="index + 1"
    :tint="color">
  </slide>
</ssr-carousel>

<ssr-carousel
  loop
  :slides-per-page="2"
  :peek="80"
  paginate-by-slide
  show-arrows
>
    <NuxtImg
        src="https://via.placeholder.com/1920x1080/BA3298/FFFFFF?text=Slide+1"
        loading="lazy"
        width="1920"
        height="1080">
    </NuxtImg>
    <NuxtImg
        src="https://via.placeholder.com/1920x1080/5E339E/FFFFFF?text=Slide+2"
        loading="lazy"
        width="1920"
        height="1080">
    </NuxtImg>
    <NuxtImg
        src="https://via.placeholder.com/1920x1080/315AAD/FFFFFF?text=Slide+3"
        loading="lazy"
        width="1920"
        height="1080">
    </NuxtImg>
</ssr-carousel>

Peeking values are responsive and support CSS units

props.code:
<ssr-carousel
  :slides-per-page="2"
  paginate-by-slide
  loop
  peek="10%"
  feather
  :responsive="[
    {
      maxWidth: 767,
      gutter: 10,
      peek: 20
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>

children.value:
<ssr-carousel
  :slides-per-page="2"
  paginate-by-slide
  loop
  peek="10%"
  feather
  :responsive="[
    {
      maxWidth: 767,
      gutter: 10,
      peek: 20
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>
prop uses your gutter value for the prop. This is useful setting when your
instance is flush with the edges of your browser and you use your site gutter value; the slides will transition out the edge of the page. Then, use the
to automatically add a light feathering mask when the viewport is wider than the carousel width.

props.code:
<ssr-carousel
  :slides-per-page="3"
  paginate-by-slide
  loop
  peek-gutter
  gutter="var(--fluid-gutter)"
  :responsive="[
    {
      minWidth: 1440,
      feather: 'calc(var(--fluid-gutter) * 0.5)'
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 768,
      slidesPerPage: 2
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 500,
      slidesPerPage: 1
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3"></slide>
  <slide :index="4"></slide>
  <slide :index="5"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>
<style lang="scss">
body {
  --fluid-gutter: 40px, 20px;
}
</style>

children.value:
<ssr-carousel
  :slides-per-page="3"
  paginate-by-slide
  loop
  peek-gutter
  gutter="var(--fluid-gutter)"
  :responsive="[
    {
      minWidth: 1440,
      feather: 'calc(var(--fluid-gutter) * 0.5)'
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 768,
      slidesPerPage: 2
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 500,
      slidesPerPage: 1
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3"></slide>
  <slide :index="4"></slide>
  <slide :index="5"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>
<style lang="scss">
body {
  --fluid-gutter: 40px, 20px;
}
</style>
This also works well without looping. Note how the peeking card switches to the left edge on the final page but the gutter on the right edge is perseved.

props.code:
<ssr-carousel
  :slides-per-page="3"
  paginate-by-slide
  peek-left="var(--fluid-gutter)"
  peek-right="calc(var(--fluid-gutter) + 30px)"
  gutter="var(--fluid-gutter)"
  :responsive="[
    {
      minWidth: 1440,
      feather: 'calc(var(--fluid-gutter) * 0.5)'
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 768,
      slidesPerPage: 2
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 500,
      slidesPerPage: 1
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3"></slide>
  <slide :index="4"></slide>
  <slide :index="5"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>

links.text: Peeking values are responsive and support CSS units

props.code:
<ssr-carousel
  :slides-per-page="4"
  :responsive="[
    {
      maxWidth: 1280,
      slidesPerPage: 3
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 1024,
      slidesPerPage: 2
    },
    {
      maxWidth: 767,
      slidesPerPage: 1
    }
  ]"
>
  <slide :index="1"></slide>
  <slide :index="2"></slide>
  <slide :index="3"></slide>
  <slide :index="4"></slide>
  <slide :index="5"></slide>
  <slide :index="6"></slide>
  <slide :index="7"></slide>
  <slide :index="8"></slide>
  <slide :index="9"></slide>
  <slide :index="10"></slide>
</ssr-carousel>

While it's not the primary use case of this package, you if you set
, the carousel will not touch the width of individual slides. Some notes:
If there are not enough slides to fill the viewport, slides will be left aligned rather than center aligned.
This hasn't been tested with responsive props or looping. Peeking doesn't make sense for this use case, but care hasn't been taken to disabling it.
Pagination controls aren't supported yet, this is purely drag only.

props.code:
<ssr-carousel :slides-per-page="null">
  <slide :index="1" :style='{ width: "65%", height: "30vw"}'></slide>
  <slide :index="2" :style='{ width: "50%", height: "30vw"}'></slide>
  <slide :index="3" :style='{ width: "30%", height: "30vw"}'></slide>
</ssr-carousel>

children.value:
<ssr-carousel :slides-per-page="null">
  <slide :index="1" :style='{ width: "65%", height: "30vw"}'></slide>
  <slide :index="2" :style='{ width: "50%", height: "30vw"}'></slide>
  <slide :index="3" :style='{ width: "30%", height: "30vw"}'></slide>
</ssr-carousel>
Here's an example where there aren't enough slides to exceed the carouel width:

props.code:
<ssr-carousel show-arrows>

  <template>
    <slide :index="1"></slide>
    <slide :index="2"></slide>
    <slide :index="3"></slide>
  </template>

  <template #back-arrow="{ disabled }">
    Back {{ disabled ? "(Disabled)" : "" }}
  </template>

  <template #next-arrow="{ disabled }">
    Next {{ disabled ? "(Disabled)" : "" }}
  </template>
</ssr-carousel>

children.value:
